name: SNMP/Syslog
description: SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol) and Syslog are essential tools for network monitoring, management, and troubleshooting. SNMP collects device statistics; Syslog records system events and messages.
key_topics: SNMP versions: v1, v2c, v3 (with authentication and encryption)
SNMP components: Manager, Agent, MIB (Management Information Base)
SNMP operations: GET, SET, TRAP, INFORM
Syslog severity levels (0-7): Emergency to Debug
Configuring Cisco device to send logs to syslog server
NTP (Network Time Protocol) for accurate timestamps
common_misconceptions: Training materials often claim SNMPv2c added security. Cisco documentation clarifies v2c only added bulk transfers and inform; community strings are still sent in cleartext. Only SNMPv3 provides real security
Many resources confuse SNMP TRAPs and INFORMs. Cisco config guides explain TRAPs are unacknowledged (UDP fire-and-forget), while INFORMs require acknowledgment (more reliable but more overhead)
Third-party books frequently overlook syslog severity levels. Cisco emphasizes understanding levels 0-7 is critical: 0=Emergency (system unusable), 7=Debug (detailed info)
Common error: not configuring NTP when using syslog. Without synchronized time across devices, correlating logs from multiple devices during troubleshooting becomes nearly impossible
